awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Next Generation Communications with Low-Resolution ADCs: Fundamentals and Practical Design
awd_abstract_narration:
As communication systems embrace ever wider bandwidths, analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) struggle to meet rate, resolution, and power requirements. The problem is exacerbated by the massive antenna arrays under consideration for next-generation wireless, which imply tens or even hundreds of receive channels. In response, this project develops new communication systems that operate with very low-resolution (e.g., 1-3 bit) ADCs. In particular, the investigators derive fundamental limits on quantized many-antenna communication and design advanced communications strategies to approach those limits.

The use of low-resolution ADCs radically changes both the theory and practice of communication, motivating a thorough re-examination of capacity bounds, modulation and coding designs, receiver processing algorithms, and limited-feedback strategies. The investigators address these topics in the context of multiple-input multiple-output systems with massive arrays. In particular, they derive theoretical capacity (or achievable rate) bounds that account for coarse ADC quantization, imperfect channel state information (CSI) at the receiver, partial CSI at the transmitter, and multi-user interference. They also characterize the mean-squared error achievable for sparse-channel estimation and the symbol-error rate achievable via equalization, both in the large-system limit. In addition, they develop limited-feedback strategies to provide transmitter CSI to the transmitter, transmitter-precoding designs that exploit that CSI, and optimized training sequences. Furthermore, they develop channel-estimation algorithms that learn and exploit channel sparsity; equalization (and/or multi-user detection) algorithms that take channel-estimation error into account; and efficient strategies for joint channel-estimation, equalization, and decoding. Finally, they develop optimization and adaptation strategies for the ADC thresholds, and blind calibration strategies that account for ADC imperfections. The research methodology leverages recent results from wireless communication theory, one-bit compressed sensing, and approximate message passing.

por.por_cntn:
Communication systems are being designed with ever wider bandwidths and ever more antennas in the hopes of provided high data rates. Unfortunately, the device that mediates between the worlds of analog and digital -- the analog-to-digital converter (ADC) -- is being rapidly pushed to its limits.  The reason is that at higher sampling rates (hundreds of mega-samples or more) and at high bits per sample, the power consumption of the ADCs becomes significant. While the absolute energy per conversion step has decreased, the rate of energy increase has seen little improvement in the past decade. One approach to overcoming this challenge is to live with low-resolution ``few-bit'' ADCs (nominally defined as 1-3 bit ADCs). Such approaches can be implemented using today's technology without requiring serendipity in circuits or semiconductor innovations.

This project focused on developing a theory of communication using low resolution ADCs at the receiver, including both fundamental limits and practical signal processing algorithms. The emphasis was placed on systems that use multiple antenna, more widely known as multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communication systems. In terms of intellectual merit, select results are summarized as follows. 

  • Channel estimation algorithms for narrowband and wideband multiple antenna communication systems. This included developing mathematical techniques that permit the estimation of the propagation channel using the signals after quantization at the receiver. Mathematical tools like compressive sensing, generalized approximate message passing, vector approximate message passing, and generalized expectation maximization, were used to develop efficient and low complexity algorithms to solve the channel estimation problem from the compressed measurements after the low-resolution ADCs.
  • An analysis of massive MIMO with low resolution ADCs. Massive MIMO is a transmission strategy involving the use of many antennas at the base station to serve users leveraging uplink or downlink multiuser MIMO techniques. Because there are many antennas, low resolution ADCs can offer a significant power savings in the massive MIMO architecture. A main development in the project was an analysis of the spectral efficiency of single-carrier and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) transmission in massive MIMO systems that use one-bit ADCs. A closed-form achievable rate, i.e., a lower bound on capacity, was derived for a wideband system with a large number of channel taps that employs low-complexity linear channel estimation and symbol detection. The results show that frequency selectivity in the channel actually leads to improved performance with low resolution ADCs. 
  • Limited feedback in MIMO systems with low resolution ADCs. Precoding in MIMO systems is a way to use the transmit antennas such that the signals are better coupled into the propagation environment. This is valuable in systems with low resolution ADCs at the receiver as the use of channel state information can help in the detection phase. Obtaining channel state information at the transmitter becomes possible with feedback from the receiver back to the transmitter. A key result is that limited feedback with ideal ADCs cannot be directly extended to the low-resolution ADCs. The reason is that additional information is required to help phase the received signals in the case of low-resolution ADCs. 
  • Hybrid architectures with low resolution ADCs. In millimeter wave communication systems, for power consumption reasons, hybrid architectures are employed where there is some analog beamforming prior to the ADCs. One main result was to quantify -- from a net power consumption perspective -- how to tradeoff energy savings due to analog beamforming and energy savings due to the use of low-resolution ADCs. The results suggest good combinations of beamforming and low resolution  

Overall, the results in this project show that it is still possible to communicate effectively even when low-resolution ADCs, as low as one-bit, are used at the receiver. 

In terms of broader impacts, the research provides a way for next generation cellular communication systems as well as local area networks, a means of exploiting higher bandwidths found at millimeter wave frequencies. Supporting data rates of tens of gigabits and beyond opens up many new applications of wireless communication to society. 

 Results from the project were disseminated widely through publications in conferences, journals, and overview articles, with early access to such publications facilitated through preprint servers. Technology transfer was facilitated by incorporating material from the project into high visibility invited talks at conferences and companies, as well as in presentations to the Wireless Networking and Communications Group industrial affiliates, and internships by the graduate students working on the project.
